Chapter IV

Aftermaths

Behind the beautiful promise of his campaign lies violence and inequalities. Inequalities that the poor, who have elected him, affects the most.

Cleavage between the rich and the poor

Inequalities in terms of Rights

Testimony

Donald Trump
×

Donald Trump

Allegeance

thought

Amnesty stresses that the police are paid to kill by their hierarchy, and identified very young victims, some are eight years old. Amnesty warns of a litany of crimes allegedly committed by police officers, such as killing defenseless people, mounting evidence, paying murderers to kill drug addicts or stealing the victims. "Police officers behave like criminals in the shallows to which they are supposed to enforce the law."
The president estimated the proportion of police officers engaged in illegal activities at 40%.

Testimony

United Nations
×

United Nations

profitability of murders

thought

The UN has called for the investigation of Rodrigo Duterte. It criticizes the incitement to violence and the killings of authorities of its country, the report evokes more than 850 extrajudicial executions. Duterte condemns a disrespectful report.
Duterte responds to the UN accusations: "You can lodge a complaint with the United Nations, I will burn the UN if I come to the United States." He even plans to leave the United Nations.

Testimony

Australia
×

australia

condamnation

thought

Few countries have closer relations with the Philippines. Over the course of their 70-year relationship, Australia and the Philippines trade on preferential terms, with almost all their goods flowing through each other's borders without incurring duties. There are more than 280 Australian companies in the Philippines, investing more than half a billion dollars and employing more than 40,000 people there.
When the Philippines has suffered natural disasters, Australia has stepped in to offer humanitarian assistance. The two countries have defence agreements that stretch back to the Second World War.

According to police statistics, from July 2015 to July 2016, Manila saw crime drop by 38%.

But there is a catch in the numbers: drug offenses may be declining, but data also indicate a
57% increase, in premeditated killings and an impressive
125% increase in homicides.

violating human rights
